Culinary Profile & Uses

1. Flavour and Form ‘Taro-Tiny’ offers the classic, comforting flavor of taro: a nutty, earthy sweetness with hints of vanilla and a texture that becomes soft and fluffy when cooked. The corms are small, rounded, and typically 5-8 cm in diameter, with distinctive concentric rings and pale flesh that may have lavender specks. The plant forms an attractive, compact cluster of upright, heart-shaped leaves on slender petioles, with some varieties showing dark purple veining or margins.

2. The Dual-Purpose Tropical Staple This taro’s compact nature makes both its roots and leaves accessible for various traditional and modern culinary applications.

  • Poached or Steamed Corms: The preferred method to enjoy its natural nutty flavor; once cooked, it can be mashed, sliced, or used as a potato alternative.
  • Taro Chips and Fries: Sliced thinly and fried or baked for a sweet, earthy snack with a beautiful pale lavender hue.
  • Taro Desserts and Paste: The key ingredient for traditional desserts like taro mochi, bubble tea, and sweet taro paste, where its color and flavor shine.
  • Cooked Young Leaves (Laing): The young, tender leaves must be cooked thoroughly to remove calcium oxalate crystals and can be used in traditional Filipino dishes like laing (taro leaves in coconut milk).

3. The Harvest and Yield ‘Taro-Tiny’ matures in one growing season, signaling readiness when the leaves begin to yellow in early autumn. The entire plant can be lifted from the container to reveal a cluster of small corms around a central mother corm. Supplied as an RFID-tagged starter tuber, a single plant provides a modest but valuable yield of 4-7 small, rounded corms totaling 300-500g, plus the bonus of ornamental, edible leaves throughout the season.
